block.p: Ernst & Young to Spin Off Business-Training Company The accounting firm Ernst & Young plans to spin off its online corporate-training operations this week as part of a strategy to become a dominant player in the crowded online corporate-training industry.

Ernst & Young hopes that the independent company, Intellinex, will be able to grow more rapidly through acquisitions than it could if it remained a part of the parent firm. There are thought to be about 5,000 players, large and small, in the online business-training industry, with new entrants appearing almost weekly. No single company holds more than 5 percent of the market. [Page C16.]

Ecompanies in Deal With Evercore Ecompanies, the Internet incubator, is expected to announce today that it is combining its venture capital arm with the new economy operations of Evercore Capital Partners, the boutique investment firm in New York. [C2.]

Niche Magazine Loses Big Sponsor The American Jewish Committee decided last week that it would pull its financial support for Common Quest, a magazine that explores the relations between blacks and Jews. An executive of the committee, which provided much of the money for the magazine, said it was exploring other ways to address the issue of relations between blacks and Jews. [C17.]

Stock and Debt Offerings Rebound The market for debt and stock offerings rebounded in the third quarter. Investment banks raised $459 billion in the United States over the last three months. That is down 10 percent from $512 billion during the period a year earlier, but the latest totals are still robust enough to make it the ninth-busiest quarter on record, based on money raised. [C2.]

Electric Cars Seek to Set Record Two electric cars with batteries made by Evonyx will depart this morning from Hawthorne, N.Y., in an attempt to make the 600-mile journey to Detroit without recharging. The feat would would smash the 373-mile record Solectria set in 1996. [C8.]

Divining the Nature of Business With the emergence of the Internet economy has come new attention to the work of Ronald Coase, who sought to explain why businesses exist as they do -- why, for instance, they choose to produce some goods but contract with outside companies to provide the rest. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C12.]
